The nomination deadline for Nobel Prizes.title: The nomination process - Nobel Peace Prize
content: The nomination process - Nobel Peace Prize
The nomination process is an eight-month screening and decision-making process.

In practice, the nomination process is an eight-month screening and decision-making process involving not only the five-member Norwegian Nobel Committee and its Secretary but also a group of Norwegian and international advisers.
The advisers, selected on the basis of their professional experience and academic expertise, prepare individual reports on the candidates that the Committee has put on its short-list.
The initial reports are usually ready by the end of April.
The Committee members then study the reports together with other relevant information and start their deliberations.
More often than not they will ask for further reports on various candidates.
As they continue their deliberations throughout the summer and receive additional reports from the advisers, they narrow the field of candidates down to a very small group.
Eventually, by the beginning of October at the latest, the Committee makes its decision through a simple majority vote.
The decision is final and without appeal.
The name(s) of that year's Nobel Peace Prize Laureate(s) is then announced.
The cycle is completed on 10 December, when the annual Nobel Peace Prize Award Ceremony takes place in the Oslo City Hall.
At the ceremony, the Laureate(s) delivers the Nobel Lecture and receives the Nobel Medal and Diploma as well as a document confirming the prize amount.

The nomination deadline for Nobel Prizes.title: Nomination and selection of Nobel Peace Prize laureates
content: Nomination and selection of Nobel Peace Prize laureates
A nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize may be submitted by any person who meets the nomination criteria.
A letter of invitation to submit is not required.
The names of the nominees and other information about the nominations cannot be revealed until 50 years later.
There are 351 candidates for the Nobel Peace Prize for 2023 out of which 259 are individuals and 92 are organisations.
351 is the second highest number of candidates ever.
For eight years in a row the number of candidates has exceeded 300.
The current record of 376 candidates was reached in 2016.
Neither the names of nominators nor of nominees for the Nobel Peace Prize may be divulged until 50 years have elapsed.
The Norwegian Nobel Committee is responsible for selecting the Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
A nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize may be submitted by any persons who are qualified to nominate.

According to the statutes of the Nobel Foundation, a nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize is considered valid if it is submitted by a person who falls within one of the following categories, a personal application for an award will not be considered: Unless otherwise stated the term ‘members’ shall be understood as current (sitting) members.
Revised in April 2018 If you belong to a group of qualified nominators, you may use the online nomination form to submit your nomination.
The candidates eligible for the Nobel Peace Prize are those persons or organisations nominated by qualified individuals, see above.
A nomination for yourself will not be taken into consideration.
The Norwegian Nobel Committee is responsible for the selection of eligible candidates and the choice of the Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
The Committee is composed of five members appointed by the Storting (Norwegian parliament).

The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded in Oslo, Norway, not in Stockholm, Sweden, where the Nobel Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Literature and the prize in economic sciences are awarded.
The nomination process for Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
Ill.
Niklas Elmehed © Nobel Media.
Ill.
Niklas Elmehed Below is a brief description of the process involved in selecting the Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
September – The Norwegian Nobel Committee prepares to receive nominations.
These nominations will be submitted by members of national assemblies, governments, and international courts of law;
university chancellors, professors of social science, history, philosophy, law and theology;
leaders of peace research institutes and institutes of foreign affairs;
previous Nobel Peace Prize laureates;
board members of organisations that have received the Nobel Peace Prize;
present and past members of the Norwegian Nobel Committee;
and former advisers of the Norwegian Nobel Institute.
February – Deadline for submission.
In order to be considered for the award of the year, nominations for the Nobel Peace Prize shall be sent in to the Norwegian Nobel Committee in Oslo before the 1st day of February the same year.
Nominations postmarked and received after this date are included in the following year’s discussions.
In recent years, the Committee has received close to 200 different nominations for different nominations for the Nobel Peace Prize.
The number of nominating letters is much higher, as many are for the same candidates.
February-March – Short list.
The Committee assesses the candidates’ work and prepares a short list.
March-August – Adviser review.
October – Nobel Prize laureates are chosen.
At the beginning of October, the Nobel Committee chooses the Nobel Peace Prize laureates through a majority vote.
The decision is final and without appeal.
The names of the Nobel Peace Prize laureates are then announced.
December – Nobel Prize laureates receive their prize.

The Nobel Peace Prize award ceremony takes place on 10 December in Oslo, Norway, where the laureates receive their Nobel Prize, which consists of a Nobel Prize medal and diploma, and a document confirming the prize amount.
The statutes of the Nobel Foundation restrict disclosure of information about the nominations, whether publicly or privately, for 50 years.
The restriction concerns the nominees and nominators, as well as investigations and opinions related to the award of a prize.
The Norwegian Nobel Committee has launched an on-line nomination form that you can use if you are a qualified nominator (see the list ‘Qualified nominators’) above).
The form can be reached from the website of the Norwegian Nobel Committee between September and February.
Nomination deadline is 31 January at 12 midnight CET.
Nominations which do not meet the deadline are normally included in the following year’s assessment.
Members of the Nobel Committee are entitled to submit their own nominations as late as at the first meeting of the Committee after the expiry of the deadline.
At the first meeting of the Nobel Committee after the February 1 deadline for nominations, the Committee’s Permanent Secretary presents the list of the year’s candidates.
The Committee may on that occasion add further names to the list, after which the nomination process is closed, and discussion of the particular candidates begins.
In the light of this first review, the Committee draws up the so-called short list – i.
e. the list of candidates selected for more thorough consideration.
The short list typically contains from twenty to thirty candidates.
The candidates on the short list are then considered by the Nobel Institute’s permanent advisers.

In addition to the Institute’s Director and Research Director, the body of advisers generally consists of a small group of Norwegian university professors with broad expertise in subject areas with a bearing on the Peace Prize.
The advisers usually have a couple of months in which to draw up their reports.
Reports are also occasionally requested from other Norwegian and foreign experts.
When the advisers’ reports have been presented, the Nobel Committee embarks on a thorough-going discussion of the most likely candidates.
In the process, the need often arises to obtain additional information and updates about candidates from additional experts, often foreign.
As a rule, the Committee reaches a decision only at its very last meeting before the announcement of the Prize at the beginning of October.
The Committee seeks to achieve unanimity in its selection of the Nobel Peace Prize laureate.
On the rare occasions when this proves impossible, the selection is decided by a simple majority vote.
The Committee does not itself announce the names of nominees, neither to the media nor to the candidates themselves.

In so far as certain names crop up in the advance speculations as to who will be awarded any given year’s prize, this is either sheer guesswork or information put out by the person or persons behind the nomination.
Information in the Nobel Committee’s nomination database is not made public until after fifty years.

For more than a century, these academic institutions have worked independently to select Nobel Prize laureates.
Several outreach organisations and activities have been developed to inspire generations and disseminate knowledge about the Nobel Prize.

Heffermehl | Nobel Peace Prize Watch – TRANSCEND Media Service Please nominate for the 2022 Nobel Peace Prize – Information below in English, French, German, Russian, Castellano and Swedish 10 Jan 2022 – By its choice for 2021 the Norwegian Nobel Committee once again demonstrated its clear determination to ignore Nobel ́s visionary idea of peace by global disarmament.
Norwegian politicians are determined to make their own prize in Nobel ́s name.
Press freedom is great, but to be a proper and legal Nobel prize the obvious choice for 2021 – relevant to demilitarization of international relations – was Julian Assange.

We in Nobel Peace Prize Watch still encourage those with nomination rights to make nominations by January 31, strictly adhering to and demanding respect for the Nobel goal of promoting global co-operation on a global peace order, based on international law, institutions and disarmament.
The Nobel Peace Prize Watch list has, since 2015, shown the type of nominations that are qualified to win, see: http://nobelwill.
org/index.
html?
tab=9.
Please act on our information, share, comment, reprint in your newsletters;
make a nomination and/or encourage others to do so.
Also, parliamentarians or professors qualified to nominate please help us by offers to take on and sign nominations that the NPPW have found it desirable to see properly entered – by Jan.
***** (Translated Versions Below) “If weapons had been the solution we would have had peace long ago.
” Trusting simple logic, the world is heading in the wrong direction, not for peace, not for security.
Nobel saw this when in 1895 he established his peace prize for global abolition of military forces.
In this way Nobel attacked the problem of war at its roots, but unfortunately he entrusted a decisive role in the selection of winners to Stortinget, the Parliament of Norway.
For decades any good person, cause of action has had a chance to win in what has become the Norwegian peace prize lottery in Nobel ́s name.

The Norwegian take-over culminated last year when Parliament rejected a proposal to make knowledge of, and loyalty to, Nobel ́s idea of peace by global co-operation and disarmament a condition for being eligible to the Nobel committee.
The proposal got only two – of 169 – votes.
Fortunately Nobel is back.

The Norwegian Nobel Committee, responding to years of criticism and political pressure from the Nobel Peace Prize Watch, now frequently mentions Alfred Nobel, his testament and his antimilitarist vision.
The prize for ICAN in 2017 promoted nuclear disarmament.

The 2018 award for Mukwege and Murad condemned sexual assault as a cruel and unacceptable weapon (but the committee has yet to denounce in clear terms the reliance on security by military weapons and the institution of the war itself).
You too can support global peace.

We suggest that for 2020 you consider nominating a qualified candidate, one within Nobel ́s idea of peace by co-operation, reforming the norms of international conduct, demilitarization, a collective security system.
Parliamentarians and professors (in certain fields) anywhere in the world belong to the groups entitled to make Nobel nominations.
If you do not have nomination rights you may ask someone who has.

Nobel Peace Prize Watch is assisting by nominating qualified candidates and pushing a most reluctant Nobel Committee to pick winners that meet Nobel ́s intention, the contemporary ideas of “creating the brotherhood of nations”, a global co-operation on the abolition of arms and military forces.
For examples illustrating who are the worthy winners in today ́s world, see our screened list at nobelwill.
org, (“Candidates 2018”).
Like Nobel we see global disarmament as the road to prosperity and security for everyone on the planet.
The Nobel idea of peace today looks unrealistic and strange to many.

Few seem able to imagine, and much less to dream of, a world without arms and militarism, and yet it still is the task – as a binding legal obligation – of the Norwegian awarders to try to raise support for Nobel ́s idea of a new, co-operative global system.
In the age of the atomic bomb time seems overripe to seriously consider Nobel ́s idea of co-operation on global disarmament.
Practical: The nomination letter must be sent by January 31 each year to: the Norwegian Nobel Committee postmaster@nobel.
no, by someone qualified to nominate (parliamentarians, professors in certain fields, earlier laureates etc.)
The farewell to Nobel ́s testament has been concealed behind strict secrecy rules.
Believing transparency will help keep the committee straight, Nobel Peace Prize Watch has, since 2015, published all known nominations we we found in compliance, on http://nobelwill.
org/index.
html?
tab=8.
Please send your nomination in ORIGINAL to postmaster@nobel.
no, and – if you think it complies with Nobel ́s purpose – a COPY to: nominations@nobelwill.
org for our evaluation and possible publication.
NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WATCH / http://www.

org Fredrik S.
Heffermehl (fredpax@online.
no, +47 917 44 783) Tomas Magnusson (gosta.
tomas@gmail.
com, +46 70 829 3197) ***** ВЫ МЕЧТАЕТЕ О НОБЕЛЕВСКОЙ ПРЕМИИ В 2020 ГОДУ .
для некоего человека, идеи или группы дорогих Вам?
“Если бы оружие было решением, мы бы обрели мир много лет назад.
” Доверяя простой логике, мир движется в неверном направлении, не к миру и не к безопасности.
Увидев это Альфред Нобель в 1895 году учредил именную премию за деятельность по укреплению мира и глобальной ликвидации вооруженных сил.
Таким образом, Нобель боролся с причинами войны, однако, к сожалению, ключевую роль в процессе выбора победителей он отдал Стортингу, парламенту Норвегии.
В течении многих десятилетий любой человек притязавший на норвежскую премию мира имел шанс выиграть в лотерее носящей имя Нобеля.

Кульминацией норвежского взлета в прошлом году стало то, что парламент отклонил предложение о том, чтобы знание и верность Нобелевской идеи прекращения огня посредством глобального сотрудничества и разоружения стали условием получения права на участие в Нобелевском комитете.
Это предложение получило только два из 169 голосов.
К счастью, Нобель вернулся.

Сегодня отвечая на многолетние критические замечания и политическое давление, связанное с Нобелевской премией мира, Норвежский Нобелевский комитет чаще всего ссылается на завещание и антимилитаристскую точку зрения Альфреда Нобеля.
Нобелевская награда в 2017 году была вручена международной общественной организации ICAN за новаторские усилия по достижению запрета на применение ядерного оружия.
В 2018 году награда была присуждена Денису Муквеге и Наде Мурад за усилия по прекращению использования сексуального насилия в качестве оружия войны.
Вы тоже можете поддержать идею глобального мира.

Мы предлагаем, чтобы в 2020 году Вы рассмотрели вопрос о выдвижении квалифицированного кандидата, поддерживающего Нобелевскую идею мира о сотрудничестве, реформировании норм международного поведения, демилитаризации и системы коллективной безопасности.
Парламентарии и профессора (в определенных областях) в независимости от того в какой точке мира находятся, принадлежат к группам, которые имеют право номинировать кандидатуры на Нобелевскую премию.
Если Вы не имеете право выдвигать кандидатуры, Вы можете обратиться с просьбой к тому, кто обладает этим правом.

Нобелевская премия мира способствует выдвижению квалифицированных кандидатов и подталкивает Нобелевский комитет к выбору победителей, наиболее соответствующих замыслу Нобеля, современным идеям «создания братства народов» и глобального сотрудничества в ликвидации оружия и вооруженных сил.
В качестве примера, смотрите размещенный нами список достойных победителей современного мира на сайте nobelwill.
org (раздел «Кандидаты 2018»).
Мы поддерживаем идеи Нобеля и рассматриваем глобальное разоружение как путь к процветанию и безопасности для всех живущих на планете.
Нобелевская идея мира сегодня выглядит нереальной и странной для многих.

Кажется, не многие способны представить себе мир без оружия и милитаризма, и тем не менее задача норвежских наград ,как юридического обязательства, заключается в попытке поддержать Нобелевскую идею по созданию новой совместной глобальной системы.
В эпоху существования атомной бомбы, кажется ушедшим время, для рассмотрения идеи Нобеля о сотрудничестве в области глобального разоружения всерьез.
Практическая часть: Номинационное письмо должно быть отправлено до 31 января каждого года в Норвежский Нобелевский комитет postmaster@nobel.

Прозрачность работы комитета помогает сохранять веру в его беспристрастность, поэтому с 2015 года на сайте Нобелевской премии мира публикуются все номинированные на премию кандидаты, которых Вы можете увидеть пройдя по ссылке: http://nobelwill.

nobelwill.

Хеффермель Томас Магнуссов Fredrik S.
Heffermehl (fredpax@online.

tomas@gmail.
com, +46 70 829 3197) ***** “Si les armes avaient été la solution, nous aurions eu la paix il y a longtemps.
” La logique simple nous dit que le monde se dirige dans la mauvaise direction, non pas vers la paix, ni la sécurité.
Nobel l’avait déjà perçue en 1895 lorsqu’il créa à Paris son prix en faveur de l’abolition mondiale des forces militaires.
Nobel s’est ainsi attaqué aux fondements des problèmes de la guerre, mais il a attribué un rôle décisif dans la sélection des lauréats au Parlement de Norvège, le Stortinget.
Pendant des décennies, toute personne, toute action ou toute cause avait une chance de remporter ce qui est devenu une sorte de loterie du prix de la paix norvégienne au nom de Nobel.

La prise de contrôle norvégienne a gagné son apogée l’année dernière lorsque le Parlement en un débat sur les critères d’éligibilité au Comité, a rejeté une proposition visant à exiger connaissance et fidélité à l’idée de paix visionnaire de Nobel.
La proposition n’a recueilli que deux votes sur un total de 169.
Heureusement, au cours de ces dernières années, la vision de Nobel est en voie de réhabilitation.

Pour faire taire les critiques et les pressions politiques exercées depuis longtemps par le Nobel Peace Prize Watch, le Comité Nobel a finalement redonné vie au testament du fondateur du Prix et à sa vision antimilitariste.
La récompense a été attribuée en 2017 à l’association ICAN pour le désarmement nucléaire et en 2018 au médecin congolais Denis Mukwege et la Yazidie Nadia Murad.
Mais en condamnant l’agression sexuelle et le viol comme armes de guerre, le comité n’a toujours pas systématiquement dénoncé les armements et la guerre en soi selon l ́intention de Nobel.

A ceux qui soutiennent l’idée d’une paix globale, rappelons que tout député du monde entier et tout professeur (en certaines disciplines) font partie de ceux et celles qui sont habilités à présenter une candidature.
Nous vous encourageons donc de nommer, en 2019, un candidat parmi ceux et celles qui ont une idée visionnaire de Nobel;
afin de réformer les normes de conduite entre gouvernements, la démilitarisation globale, la coopération, la sécurité collective.
Tous ceux qui sont dépourvus d’un droit de nomination peuvent s’adresser à ceux qui l’ont.
Nobel Peace Prize Watch offre son soutien et son aide a tout candidat qualifié.
Il est disposé à dépasser les réticences du comité Nobel afin que celui-ci choisisse des lauréats qui répondent aux vœux du testament antimilitariste de Nobel.

Il avait l’intention de soutenir les idées très contemporaines pour «réaliser une fraternité des nations», une coopération mondiale en vue de l’abolition global des armes et des forces militaires.
Pour des exemples qui donnent une idée de gagnants dignes du monde d’aujourd’hui, consultez sur http://www.
nobelwill.
org, sous l ́onglet «Candidates 2018», notre liste de dépistage.
Toute comme Alfred Nobel, nous considérons le désarmement comme la seule voie permettant la prospérité et la sécurité pour tous sur la planète.
Certes, l’idée de paix véhiculée par Nobel peut apparaître aujourd’hui comme irréaliste et étrange.
D’ailleurs, nombreux sont ceux qui semblent incapables d’imaginer un monde sans armes ni militarisme, et encore moins d ́en rêver.
Cependant, susciter l’appui en faveur d’un système mondial coopératif demeure la tâche – en tant qu’obligation juridique contraignante – du comité norvégien.
À l’ère des arsenaux atomiques, il est temps d ́examiner sérieusement l’idée diffusée par Nobel de la coopération entre les pays pour le désarmement mondial.
Instructions pratiques: La lettre de nomination envoyé par une personne qualifiée pour la nomination (parlementaire, professeur dans certains domaines, lauréats précédents, etc.)
doit être envoyée au plus tard le 31 janvier de chaque année à l’adresse suivante: postmaster@nobel.
no.
Le comité Nobel a pu cacher son congé du testament pendant beaucoup d ́années derrière des règles strictes de confidentialité.

Depuis 2015 Nobel Peace Prize Watch, convaincu de la valeur de transparence pour garder le comité en règle, a publié toutes les candidatures que nous avons jugées conformes au testament, sur les pages internet http://nobelwill.
org/index.
html?
tab=8.
Nous vous invitons à partager une copie de votre nomination pour évaluation et publication en envoyant l ́ORIGINAL au Comité Nobel à postmaster@nobel.
no et une COPIE à: nominations@nobelwill.
org).
NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WATCH / http://www.
nobelwill.
org Fredrik S.
Heffermehl Tomas Magnusson (fredpax@online.
tomas@gmail.
com, +46 70 829 3197) ***** “Wären Waffen die Lösung, hätten wir längst Frieden.
” Es ist einfache Logik dass die Welt sich in die falsche Richtung bewegt, nicht auf dem Weg zum Frieden, nicht auf dem Weg zur Sicherheit.
Nobel sah dies schon als er 1895 seinen Friedenspreis der weltweiten Abschaffung aller militärer Streitkräfte widmete.
Auf diese Weise griff Nobel das Problem des Krieges an den Wurzeln an, aber leider vertraute er eine entscheidende Rolle bei der Wahl der Gewinner dem norwegischen Parlament, Stortinget, an.
Seit Jahrzehnten hat jede gute Mensch, Sache oder Handlung die Chance gehabt, die norwegische Friedenslotterie im Namen Nobels zu gewinnen.
Die norwegische Übernahme fand ihren Höhepunkt im vergangenen Jahr, als das Parlament im Herbst die Qualifikationskriterien für das Komitee besprach.
Ein Antrag, Kenntnis und Loyalität gegenüber Nobels visionärer Friedensidee zu fordern wurde massiv zurückgewiesen.
Der Antrag erhielt nur zwei – von 169 – Stimmen (mehr darüber in https://www.
rubikon.
news/artikel/die-waffen-nieder-2.)
Zum Glück, in den letzten Jahren ist Nobel wieder da.

Das norwegische Nobel-Komitee, das auf jahrelange Kritik und politischen Druck seitens der Nobel Peace Prize Watch reagiert, erwähnt nun häufig Alfred Nobel, sein Testament und seine antimilitaristische Vision.
Der Preis für ICAN im Jahr 2017 förderte die nukleare Abrüstung.
Der Preis für Mukwege und Murad von 2018 definierte sexuelle Übergriffe als grausame und inakzeptable Waffe im Krieg.
(Das Komitee müsste jedoch auch das Vertrauen in die Sicherheit durch militärische Waffen und den Krieg selbst anprangern).

Wir schlagen vor, dass Sie im Jahr 2019 erwägen, einen qualifizierten Kandidaten zu nominieren, einen der Nobels Idee entspricht, und sich für Frieden durch Zusammenarbeit um die Normen für internationales Verhalten zu reformieren, für Entmilitarisierung und ein kollektives Sicherheitssystem einsetzt.
Parlamentarier und Professoren (in bestimmten Bereichen) auf der ganzen Welt gehören zu den Gruppen, die berechtigt sind, Nobel-Nominierungen zu machen.
Wenn Sie kein solches Recht haben, können Sie jemanden fragen, der dieses Recht hat.
Nobel Peace Prize Watch hilft qualifizierten Kandidaten nominiert zu werden und will das Nobel-Komitee beeinflussen Gewinner auszusuchen, die dem antimilitaristischen Testament von Nobel entsprechen.

Nobel beabsichtigte, zeitgenössische Ideen der “Schaffung der Brüderlichkeit der Nationen” und der globalen Zusammenarbeit bei der Abschaffung von Waffen (inspiriert durch Bertha von Suttners „Die Waffen nieder!
“) zu unterstützen.
Wie Nobel sehen wir weltweite Abrüstung als den Weg zu Wohlstand und Sicherheit für alle Menschen der Welt.
Würdige Gewinner finden Sie in unserer Screening-Liste: nobelwill.
org (“Candidates 2018”).
Die damaligen Friedensideen mögen heutzutage unrealistisch und fremd wirken.
Nur wenige können sich heute eine Welt ohne Waffen und Militarismus vorstellen.
Aber es ist eine zwingende rechtliche Verpflichtung der norwegischen Preisverleiher, Nobels Idee zu fördern.
Im Zeitalter der Atombombe scheint die Zeit überreif zu sein, Nobels Idee einer Kooperation bei der globalen Abrüstung ernsthaft in Betracht zu ziehen.
Praktisches Vorgehen: Das Nominierungsschreiben muss bis zum 31.
Januar eines jeden Jahres an das norwegische Nobelkomitee postmaster@nobel.
no gesendet werden von einer Person, die qualifiziert ist (Parlamentarier, Professoren in bestimmten Bereichen, frühere Preisträger usw.)
Der Abschied mit Nobels Testament hat sich jahrelang hinter strengen Geheimhaltungsregeln verbergt.

Nobel Peace Prize Watch“, die an Transparenz glaubt, hat seit 2015 – um das Komité zu dem Gesetz zu halten – alle uns bekannte Nominierungen veröffentlicht, die wir für qualifiziert befunden hat (siehe Liste auf http://nobelwill.
org/index.
html?
tab=8).

Wir bitten Sie höflichst, uns eine Kopie von vermutlich qualifizerten Kandidaten zu unserer Evaluierung und mögliche Veröffentlichung mitzuteilen (Adresse für die Nomination – ORIGINAL: postmaster@nobel.
no, Kopie an uns: nominations@nobelwill.
org).
NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WATCH / http://www.
nobelwill.
org Fredrik S.
Heffermehl Tomas Magnusson (fredpax@online.
tomas@gmail.
com, +46 70 829 3197) ***** “Si las armas fuesen la solución, hace mucho tendríamos paz”.
Es lógica simple que el mundo va en la dirección equivocada, no a la paz, no a la seguridad.
Nobel entendió esto cuando, en 1895, estableció su premio de la paz por la abolición global de las fuerzas militares.
De esta manera, Nobel atacó el problema de la guerra desde sus raíces, pero desafortunadamente, confió un papel decisivo en la selección de los ganadores a Stortinget, el Parlamento de Noruega.
Durante décadas, cualquier persona, causa o acción buena, han tenido la oportunidad de ganar lo que se ha convertido en la lotería del premio de la paz noruego a nombre de Nobel.

La toma de posesión noruega culminó el año pasado quando Stortinget discutió los requisitos de elegibilidad para incorporación al comité, y una propuesta para exigir a los aspirantes conocimiento y lealtad a la idea visionaria de la paz y desarme de Nobel, obtuvo solo dos – de un total de 169 – votos.
Afortunadamente Nobel está de vuelta.

El Comité Nobel noruego, respondiendo a años de críticas y presiones políticas del Nobel Peace Prize Watch, ahora menciona con frecuencia a Alfred Nobel, su testamento y su visión antimilitarista.
El premio para ICAN en 2017 promovió el desarme nuclear.
El premio de 2018 para Mukwege y Murad condenó el asalto sexual como un arma cruel e inaceptable (pero el comité aún no denunció las armas y la institución de la guerra en sí).
Tú también puedes apoyar la paz global.

Sugerimos que en 2019 consideres nominar a un candidato quien conforme a la idea visionaria de paz de Nobel mediante la cooperación en la reforma de las normas de conducta inter naciones, promueva y divulgue la desmilitarización y un sistema de seguridad colectiva.

Nobel Peace Prize Watch está asistiendo al nominar candidatos calificados y al Comité Nobel (reticentemente) a concentrarse en los ganadores que cumplen con la intención de Nobel, a apoyar las ideas contemporáneas de “crear la hermandad de naciones”, una cooperación global para la abolición de armas y fuerzas militares.
Para ver ejemplos que ilustran quiénes son los ganadores dignos en el mundo de hoy, vea nuestra lista hoy, vea nuestra lista de candidatos calificados 2018 en nobelwill.
org (“Candidates 2018”).
Como Nobel, vemos el desarme global como el camino hacia la prosperidad y la seguridad para todos en el planeta.
La idea de paz de Nobel hoy parece poco realista y extraña para muchos.
Pocos parecen capaces de imaginar, y mucho menos de soñar, a un mundo sin armas y sin militarismo, pero aún así esta es la obligación legal vinculante de los custodios noruegos.
Deben reflexionar sobre la idea que Alfred Nobel deseaba apoyar, un nuevo sistema global cooperativo entre sociedades, y promover ella.

En la era de la bomba atómica y otras tecnologías de destrucción masiva y aniquilación, la idea de la cooperación de Nobel para el desarme global parece ser la única alternativa para detener el biocida actual (Corina Toledo).
Práctico: la carta de nominación debe enviarse antes del 31 de enero de cada año a: Comité Nobel Noruego postmaster@nobel.
no, por alguien calificado para nominar (parlamentarios, profesores en ciertos campos, anteriores galardonados, etc.)
La desviación al testamento y pensamiento de Nobel se ha ocultado detrás de estrictas reglas de confidencialidad.
Nuestra convicción es que la transparencia debe influir al comité a seguir el testamento y los leyes.
Desde 2015 hemos publicado todas las nominaciones conocidas que consideramos de conformidad con el testamento en http://nobelwill.
org/index.
html?
tab=8.
Le recomendamos que comparta una copia de su nominación para evaluación y posible publication (Carta ORIGINAL a postmaster@nobel.
no, COPIA a: nominations@nobelwill.
org).
NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WATCH / http://www.
nobelwill.
org Fredrik S.
Heffermehl Tomas Magnusson (fredpax@online.
tomas@gmail.
com, +46 70 829 3197) *** “Om vapen hade varit lösningen skulle vi ha haft fred för länge sedan.
” Den enklaste logik säger oss att världen går i fel riktning, inte mot fred, inte mot säkerhet.
Nobel såg detta redan när han 1895 etablerade sitt fredspris för globalt avskaffande av militära styrkor.
På detta sätt attackerade Nobel krigets rötter, men tyvärr anförtrodde han en avgörande roll i valet av pristagare till Stortinget, Norges parlament.
I årtionden har varje bra person, sak, eller handling haft en chans att vinna i det som har blivit det norska fredsprislotteriet i Nobels namn.

Norska politikers övertagande av priset kulminerade förra året när parlamentet avvisade ett förslag att göra kunskap om och lojalitet gentemot Nobels idé om fred och nedrustning till ett villkor för att kunna väljas till Nobelkommittén.
Förslaget fick bara två – av totalt 169 – röster.
Lyckligtvis är Nobel tillbaka.

Efter år av kritik och politiskt tryck från Nobel Peace Prize Watch nämner nu Norska Nobelkommitté ofta Alfred Nobel, hans testamente och – med knappt hörbar röst – hans antimilitaristiska fredsvision.
Priset till ICAN år 2017 främjade nukleär nedrustning.
2018 fördömde priset till Mukwege och Murad sexuella övergrepp som ett grymt och oacceptabelt vapen (men fördömde ännu inte alla vapen och kriget som institution).
Du kan också stödja global fred.

Vare sig du är bland dem som har rätt att göra Nobel-nomineringar eller måste hitta någon sådan föreslår vi att du 2019 överväger att nominera en kandidat som svarar mot Nobels visionära idé om fred genom insatser för reform av normerna för internationellt beteende och global demilitarisering inom ett kollektivt säkerhetssystem.
Nobels idé om fred kan idag förefalla orealistisk och konstig för många.
Få verkar kunna föreställa sig, och än mindre drömma om, en värld utan vapen och militarism.
Men det är fortfarande en laglig bindande skyldighet för norska Nobelkommittén att stödja Nobels idé om ett nytt, kooperativt globalt fredssystem.
I atombombens ålder verkar tiden mer än mogen för att seriöst överväga Nobels idé om samarbete för global nedrustning.
Vi tycker det är en mycket bra idé, även med klimatet och andra brådskande hot emot vår gemensamma framtid i åtanke.

Nobel Peace Prize Watch bistår med att nominera kvalificerade kandidater och influera en rätt motvillig Nobelkommitté att välja pristagare som motsvarar Nobels intention om att stödja samtida idéer om “folkens förbrödrande” (skapa ett broderskap av nationer), främjande av fredskongresser och ett globalt samarbete om avskaffande av vapen och militära styrkor.
Exempel på vilka som är värdiga prisvinnare i dagens värld finns i vår screenade lista på nobelwill.
org, (under “Kandidater 2018”).
Liksom Nobel ser vi global nedrustning som vägen till välstånd och säkerhet för alla på planeten.
Praktiskt: Nomineringsbrevet ska skickas senast den 31 januari varje år till: Norska Nobelkommittén postmaster@nobel.
no, av någon som är kvalificerad att nominera (parlamentariker, professorer på vissa områden, tidigare pristagare etc.)
Farvälet till Nobels testamente har under många år dolts bakom strikta sekretessregler.
Nobel Peace Prize Watch, som tror att öppenhet kommer att bidra till att hålla Nobelkommittén på rätt spår, har på http://nobelwill.
org/index.
html?

The final decision for Nobel Prizes is m.title: Nomination and selection of Nobel Peace Prize laureates
content: Nomination and selection of Nobel Peace Prize laureates
A nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize may be submitted by any person who meets the nomination criteria.
A letter of invitation to submit is not required.
The names of the nominees and other information about the nominations cannot be revealed until 50 years later.
There are 351 candidates for the Nobel Peace Prize for 2023 out of which 259 are individuals and 92 are organisations.
351 is the second highest number of candidates ever.
For eight years in a row the number of candidates has exceeded 300.
The current record of 376 candidates was reached in 2016.
Neither the names of nominators nor of nominees for the Nobel Peace Prize may be divulged until 50 years have elapsed.
The Norwegian Nobel Committee is responsible for selecting the Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
A nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize may be submitted by any persons who are qualified to nominate.

According to the statutes of the Nobel Foundation, a nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize is considered valid if it is submitted by a person who falls within one of the following categories, a personal application for an award will not be considered: Unless otherwise stated the term ‘members’ shall be understood as current (sitting) members.
Revised in April 2018 If you belong to a group of qualified nominators, you may use the online nomination form to submit your nomination.
The candidates eligible for the Nobel Peace Prize are those persons or organisations nominated by qualified individuals, see above.
A nomination for yourself will not be taken into consideration.
The Norwegian Nobel Committee is responsible for the selection of eligible candidates and the choice of the Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
The Committee is composed of five members appointed by the Storting (Norwegian parliament).

The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded in Oslo, Norway, not in Stockholm, Sweden, where the Nobel Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, Physiology or Medicine, Literature and the prize in economic sciences are awarded.
The nomination process for Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
Ill.
Niklas Elmehed © Nobel Media.
Ill.
Niklas Elmehed Below is a brief description of the process involved in selecting the Nobel Peace Prize laureates.
September – The Norwegian Nobel Committee prepares to receive nominations.
These nominations will be submitted by members of national assemblies, governments, and international courts of law;
university chancellors, professors of social science, history, philosophy, law and theology;
leaders of peace research institutes and institutes of foreign affairs;
previous Nobel Peace Prize laureates;
board members of organisations that have received the Nobel Peace Prize;
present and past members of the Norwegian Nobel Committee;
and former advisers of the Norwegian Nobel Institute.
February – Deadline for submission.
In order to be considered for the award of the year, nominations for the Nobel Peace Prize shall be sent in to the Norwegian Nobel Committee in Oslo before the 1st day of February the same year.
Nominations postmarked and received after this date are included in the following year’s discussions.
In recent years, the Committee has received close to 200 different nominations for different nominations for the Nobel Peace Prize.
The number of nominating letters is much higher, as many are for the same candidates.
February-March – Short list.
The Committee assesses the candidates’ work and prepares a short list.
March-August – Adviser review.
October – Nobel Prize laureates are chosen.
At the beginning of October, the Nobel Committee chooses the Nobel Peace Prize laureates through a majority vote.
The decision is final and without appeal.
The names of the Nobel Peace Prize laureates are then announced.
December – Nobel Prize laureates receive their prize.

The Nobel Peace Prize award ceremony takes place on 10 December in Oslo, Norway, where the laureates receive their Nobel Prize, which consists of a Nobel Prize medal and diploma, and a document confirming the prize amount.
The statutes of the Nobel Foundation restrict disclosure of information about the nominations, whether publicly or privately, for 50 years.
The restriction concerns the nominees and nominators, as well as investigations and opinions related to the award of a prize.
The Norwegian Nobel Committee has launched an on-line nomination form that you can use if you are a qualified nominator (see the list ‘Qualified nominators’) above).
The form can be reached from the website of the Norwegian Nobel Committee between September and February.
Nomination deadline is 31 January at 12 midnight CET.
Nominations which do not meet the deadline are normally included in the following year’s assessment.
Members of the Nobel Committee are entitled to submit their own nominations as late as at the first meeting of the Committee after the expiry of the deadline.
At the first meeting of the Nobel Committee after the February 1 deadline for nominations, the Committee’s Permanent Secretary presents the list of the year’s candidates.
The Committee may on that occasion add further names to the list, after which the nomination process is closed, and discussion of the particular candidates begins.
In the light of this first review, the Committee draws up the so-called short list – i.
e. the list of candidates selected for more thorough consideration.
The short list typically contains from twenty to thirty candidates.
The candidates on the short list are then considered by the Nobel Institute’s permanent advisers.

In addition to the Institute’s Director and Research Director, the body of advisers generally consists of a small group of Norwegian university professors with broad expertise in subject areas with a bearing on the Peace Prize.
The advisers usually have a couple of months in which to draw up their reports.
Reports are also occasionally requested from other Norwegian and foreign experts.
When the advisers’ reports have been presented, the Nobel Committee embarks on a thorough-going discussion of the most likely candidates.
In the process, the need often arises to obtain additional information and updates about candidates from additional experts, often foreign.
As a rule, the Committee reaches a decision only at its very last meeting before the announcement of the Prize at the beginning of October.
The Committee seeks to achieve unanimity in its selection of the Nobel Peace Prize laureate.
On the rare occasions when this proves impossible, the selection is decided by a simple majority vote.
The Committee does not itself announce the names of nominees, neither to the media nor to the candidates themselves.

In so far as certain names crop up in the advance speculations as to who will be awarded any given year’s prize, this is either sheer guesswork or information put out by the person or persons behind the nomination.
Information in the Nobel Committee’s nomination database is not made public until after fifty years.

The final decision for Nobel Prizes is m.title: How does the Nobel Peace Prize work? | Reuters
content: How does the Nobel Peace Prize work? | Reuters
[1/2]A Nobel Prize medal replica is on display inside the Norwegian Nobel Institute in Oslo, Norway September 19, 2022.
REUTERS/Victoria Klesty/File Photo Acquire Licensing Rights OSLO, Oct 3 (Reuters) - The winner of the 2022 Nobel Peace Prize will be announced on Oct.
7 in Oslo.

Here is a look at how the award works: The prize should go to the person "who has done the most or best to advance fellowship among nations, the abolition or reduction of standing armies, and the establishment and promotion of peace congresses", according to the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, the inventor of dynamite, who founded the awards.
Thousands of people can propose names: members of governments and parliaments;
current heads of state;
university professors of history, social sciences, law and philosophy;
and former Nobel Peace Prize laureates, among others.
This year there are 343 nominees, although the full list will be kept locked away in a vault for 50 years.
Among oddsmakers' favourites this year are the Kyiv Independent newspaper, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and the United Nations' refugee agency (UNHCR).
The Norwegian Nobel Committee, which consists of five individuals appointed by the Norwegian parliament.
Members are often retired politicians, but not always.
The current committee is led by a lawyer and includes an academic.
They are all put forward by Norwegian political parties and their appointments reflect the balance of power in Norway's parliament.
Nominations close on Jan.
Members of the committee can make their own nominations no later than at the first meeting of the committee in February.
They discuss all the nominations, then establish a shortlist.
Each nominee is then assessed and examined by a group of permanent advisers and other experts.
The committee meets roughly once a month to discuss the nominations.
They usually make their decision at the final committee meeting, which tends to be at the beginning of October.
The committee seeks a consensus on its selection.
If it can't, the decision is reached by majority vote.
The last time a member quit in protest was in 1994, when Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat shared the prize with Israel's Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Rabin.
While the full list of nominations is kept secret, nominators are free to disclose them.
In recent years, Norway's own lawmakers have tended to release names of their nominees in advance, with a run of success: seven of the last nine winners appeared on those lists.

This year, according to a Reuters survey of Norwegian lawmakers who have disclosed their nominees, the list includes Sweden's Greta Thunberg and Fridays for Future, Belarus dissidents Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, Maria Kolesnikova and Veronika Tsepkalo.
They have also nominated Russia's Alexei Navalny, Pope Francis, British nature broadcaster David Attenborough, Tuvalu's foreign minister Simon Kofe and the World Health Organization.
A medal, a diploma, ten million Swedish crowns ($900,000) - and immediate global attention.
South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu, the 1984 laureate, has said becoming a Nobel laureate was a double-edged sword.
"One day no one was listening.
The next, I was an oracle," he is quoted as saying in his authorised biography.
The announcement will be made at 1100 CET (0900 GMT) on Friday at the Norwegian Nobel Institute in Oslo by the chair of the Norwegian Nobel Committee, Berit Reiss-Andersen.
The ceremony will take place at the Oslo City Hall on Dec.
10, the anniversary of Alfred Nobel's death.
1081 Swedish crowns) Compiled by Gwladys Fouche, Editing by William Maclean Our Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.
Thomson Reuters Oversees news coverage from Norway for Reuters and loves flying to Svalbard in the Arctic, oil platforms in the North Sea, and guessing who is going to win the Nobel Peace Prize.
Born in France and with Reuters since 2010, she has worked for The Guardian, Agence France-Presse and Al Jazeera English, among others, and speaks four languages.

For Angus Deaton – awarded the Prize in Economic Sciences 2015 – fly fishing has helped him think in new and creative ways © Nobel Media.
Photo: Alexander Mahmoud In 1968, Sveriges Riksbank (Sweden’s central bank) established the Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, founder of the Nobel Prize.
The prize is based on a donation received by the Nobel Foundation in 1968 from Sveriges Riksbank on the occasion of the bank’s 300th anniversary.
The first prize in economic sciences was awarded to Ragnar Frisch and Jan Tinbergen in 1969.
The prize in economic sciences is awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, Stockholm, Sweden, according to the same principles as for the Nobel Prizes that have been awarded since 1901.
See all economic sciences laureates or learn about the nomination process.

Photo: Nobel Prize Museum The Tinbergen brothers The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 1969-2007 Angus Deaton employed theory, data collection and statistics together to see how consumption, poverty, and welfare are related.
His conclusion?
We need to understand individual consumption choices before we can design economic policy that promotes welfare and reduces poverty.

In 1968, a new prize in economic science.title: Facts on the prize in economic sciences - NobelPrize.org
content: Facts on the prize in economic sciences - NobelPrize.org
Herbert Simon's set of chess that he chose to donate to the Nobel Museum in Stockholm, Sweden.
© Nobel Media.
Photo: Alexander Mahmoud In 1968, Sveriges Riksbank (Sweden’s central bank) established this prize in memory of Alfred Nobel, founder of the Nobel Prize.
Here are some facts and figures regarding The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, awarded from 1969 to 2023.
55 prizes in economic sciences have been awarded every year since 1969.
26 prizes in economic sciences have been given to one laureate only.
20 prizes in economic sciences have been shared by two laureates.
9 prizes in economic sciences have been shared between three laureates.
93 individuals have been awarded 1969-2023.
List of all economic sciences laureates To date, the youngest economic sciences laureate is Esther Duflo, who was 46 years old when she was awarded in 2019.
The oldest economic sciences laureate to date is Leonid Hurwicz, who was 90 years old when he was awarded in 2007.
Elinor Ostrom became the first female economic sciences laureate when awarded the prize in 2009.
Esther Duflo was awarded the prize in 2019 and Claudia Goldin in 2023.
List of all female Nobel Prize laureates So far there are no multiple economic sciences laureates.
Multiple Nobel Prize laureates within other prize categories There have been no posthumous prizes in economic sciences.
From 1974, the Statutes of the Nobel Foundation stipulate that a prize cannot be awarded posthumously, unless death has occurred after the announcement of the prize.
Before 1974, the Nobel Prize has only been awarded posthumously twice: to Dag Hammarskjöld (Nobel Peace Prize 1961) and Erik Axel Karlfeldt (Nobel Prize in Literature 1931).
However, William Vickrey passed away just a few days after the announcement, and was not able to accept the prize in person.

Brothers: Jan Tinbergen (economic sciences prize 1969) and Nikolaas Tinbergen (medicine prize 1973) Married couple:Gunnar Myrdal (economic sciences prize 1974) and Alva Myrdal (peace prize 1982) The medal in economic sciences was designed by Swedish artist and sculptor Gunvor Svensson-Lundqvist and shows the North Star emblem of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.
Read more about the medal for the prize in economic sciences Each diploma is a unique work of art, created by foremost Swedish and Norwegian artists and calligraphers.
More about the diplomas Thomas J.

Sargent – Nobel Diploma Copyright © The Nobel Foundation 2011, Artist: Susanne Jardeback, Calligrapher: Annika Rücker, Book binder: Ingemar Dackéus, Photo reproduction: Lovisa Engblom Alfred Nobel left most of his estate, more than SEK 31 million (today approximately SEK 1,702 million) to be converted into a fund and invested in “safe securities.
” The income from the investments was to be “distributed annually in the form of prizes to those who during the preceding year have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.
” The prize amount for 2023 is set at Swedish kronor (SEK) 11.
0 million per full prize.
More about the prize amount *Why are the individuals awarded a prize in economic sciences called laureates?
The word “laureate” refers to being signified by the laurel wreath.
In Greek mythology, the god Apollo is represented wearing a laurel wreath on his head.
A laurel wreath is a circular crown made of branches and leaves of the bay laurel (in Latin: Laurus nobilis).
In Ancient Greece, laurel wreaths were awarded to victors as a sign of honour – both in athletic competitions and in poetic meets.

Several outreach organisations and activities have been developed to inspire generations and disseminate knowledge about the Nobel Prize.

content: The 'Rule of Three' in Nobel Prizes: An Analysis
Quick links Quick links Sign up for our daily newsletter covering global breaking news around the world.
By signing up, you agree to the our terms and our our agreement.
One of the most prestigious recognitions in the world, the Nobel Prizes, have been honoring exceptional contributions in various fields for over a century.
However, a particular rule associated with these awards, known as the ‘rule of three’, has been stirring debates and discussions among the scientific and academic communities.
The rule states that a maximum of three laureates can share a Nobel prize.
This limitation, though in effect since the inception of the awards, has been criticized for potentially overlooking other contributors to a prize-winning discovery or achievement.
This analysis delves into the implications of the ‘rule of three’, its pros and cons, and its impact on the recognition of achievements in various fields.
The ‘rule of three’ traces its origins back to the will of Alfred Nobel, the founder of the Nobel Prizes.
According to his will, the prizes were to be awarded to those who, during the preceding year, conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.
The rule of limiting the prize to a maximum of three laureates ensures that the contribution of each laureate is significant and not diluted.
It also helps maintain the prestige and exclusivity of the awards.
While the rule ensures that the laureates’ contributions are substantial, it does have its drawbacks.
In many cases, especially in scientific discoveries and advancements, contributions are made by more than three individuals or entities.
The ‘rule of three’ can potentially exclude deserving contributors from being recognized.

For instance, in the case of the revolutionary gene-editing technique, CRISPR, Eric Lander, President and founding director of the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, argued that about a dozen people deserve tremendous credit for its discovery.
The Nobel Prize’s ‘rule of three’, however, made it impossible to recognize all of them.
The limitation of the Nobel Prize to three laureates has sparked controversies on several occasions.
Notably, the awarding of the 2013 Nobel Prize in Physics for the Higgs boson prediction was fraught with controversy.

Peter Higgs and François Englert were awarded the prize, while other contributors like Gerald Guralnik, Carl Richard Hagen, and Tom Kibble, who published significant papers on the topic the same year, were left out due to the ‘rule of three’.
This case sparked discussions on whether the rule should be reconsidered to ensure fair recognition of all significant contributors.
Despite the criticism and debates, changing the ‘rule of three’ for the Nobel Prizes is a complex issue.
It would not only require revisiting Alfred Nobel’s will but also re-evaluating the purpose and philosophy of the awards.

While some argue that the rule ensures the exclusivity and prestige of the awards, others contend that it is time to rethink the rule to accommodate the collaborative nature of modern scientific discoveries and advancements.

The debate continues, and it remains to be seen whether the ‘rule of three’ will stand the test of time or be revised to resonate with the evolving landscapes of science, literature, peace, and economic sciences.

In 2012, a new rule was introduced that.title: What the Nobel Prizes get wrong about science | CNN
content: What the Nobel Prizes get wrong about science | CNN
Sign up for CNN’s Wonder Theory science newsletter.
Explore the universe with news on fascinating discoveries, scientific advancements and more.
Some of the most brilliant minds in science will be catapulted from academic obscurity this week when the Nobel Prizes in physics, chemistry, and medicine or physiology are announced.

The honors, established by Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel more than a century ago, represent the pinnacle of scientific achievement, celebrating transformative breakthroughs that are often decades in the making.
Opinion: 70 years ago, the structure of DNA was revealed.
Was Rosalind Franklin robbed?

In addition to the huge publicity, the prizes also draw their share of flak, sometimes triggering controversy and resentment over who gets chosen and who is left out, said Martin Rees, British cosmologist and physicist and former president of the Royal Society, the world’s oldest scientific society.
Rees said one challenge for the Nobel committees is the increasingly collaborative nature of most scientific research.
The image of the lone genius having a eureka moment is long gone, if it ever truly existed.

Additionally, discoveries can be made simultaneously by different teams. However, the Nobel selection committees, according to the rules laid down by Alfred Nobel in 1895, can only honor up to three people per prize.
This requirement can prove to be a headache, Rees said.
“It may be a project where several people have done work in parallel, and they single out some and not others.

It may be that there’s a team, and it’s not obvious that the ones they’ve singled from the team are the dominant figures,” said Rees, who is the UK’s astronomer royal and author of “If Science Is to Save Us.
” For example, the 2017 Nobel in physics recognized the detection of gravitational waves — “ripples” in space generated by colliding black holes 1 billion or more light-years away.
The key papers reporting this discovery had almost 1,000 authors, Rees noted.
However, only three were rewarded the prize — Rainer Weiss, Barry Barish and Kip Thorne.

Similarly, one often discussed candidate for the medicine or chemistry Nobel Prize is the mapping of the human genome, a transformative project that was only fully completed in 2022 and involved hundreds of people.

David Pendlebury, head of research analysis at Clarivate’s Institute for Scientific Information, who identifies “Nobel worthy” individuals by analyzing how often fellow scientists cite their key scientific papers throughout the years, agrees that the three-person rule is a constraint.
“It really has become a huge transformation in science that it’s more and more team science — huge groups tackling more difficult problems, international collaborative networks,” Pendlebury said.
“This rule of three does seem to be an impediment if they wanted to recognize a team.

” The rule that a prize can only be awarded to three people comes from the statutes of the Nobel Foundation, which is responsible for fulfilling the intentions of Nobel’s will, according to the Nobel Prize website.
Peter Brzezinski, the secretary of the committee for the Nobel chemistry prize, said there were no plans to change the rule.
However, he said that the committee follows a detailed process once the nominations have been made by the end of January.

“We start the process by asking a number of experts from around the world to write reports describing the field in which the discovery has been made, to outline the main discoveries in this field and also to mention individuals who have made the most important contributions,” he explained via email.
“We read all relevant literature, attend conferences and write reports also within the committee,” Brzezinski added.
“With time, we often succeed in identifying a limited number of scientists who have made the discovery.
If this is not possible, we are not able to propose a Prize to the Academy.

” The Nobel committees typically single out work that happened decades earlier — a retrospective view that’s often needed given that it can take time for the significance of some scientific research to become clear.
The Nobels also focus on three scientific disciplines, as designated in the will of Alfred Nobel.
Fields including mathematics, computer science, earth and climate science and oceanography are excluded.

Nose hairs, dead spiders and licking rocks are among this year’s Ig Nobel Prize-winning topics Even within the fields of chemistry, physics and medicine and physiology, just five areas out of 114 different scientific subdisciplines account for more than half of Nobel Prizes awarded from 1995 to 2017, according to one 2020 study.
These are particle physics, atomic physics, cell biology, neuroscience and molecular chemistry.
Rees, however, noted that taking the long view and giving greater recognition to certain fields can, at times, make the Nobel committees seem out of touch with the scientific priorities of the day.
One example is artificial intelligence, or AI, which is transforming people’s lives at an unprecedented pace.
Two hot names in the field are Demis Hassabis and John Jumper, the Google DeepMind inventors of AlphaFold — an AI program that decodes the 3D structures of proteins from amino acid sequences.
They won the $250,000 Lasker Prize this year and the Breakthrough Prize a year earlier.
Since their key paper was published just over two years ago, it has been cited more than 8,500 times, Pendlebury said.

Meet the man who has transformed our understanding of evolution “That is, in my experience, just incredible in terms of the speed at which the citations have accrued, so obviously, it’s a huge, important intellectual discovery,” said Pendlebury, who has been compiling his list of “citation laureates” since 2002.

The Nobel committees have on occasion awarded accolades to recent breakthroughs — such as when the chemistry prize went to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer Doudna in 2020, less than 10 years after their key 2012 paper on the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique — but Pendlebury thinks a Nobel Prize for AI this year is still a long shot.
He said the Nobel Prize committees, at least for science prizes, are “innately conservative.
” Other criticism leveled at the Nobel Prizes includes the lack of diversity among winners.
More female scientists have gotten the call from Stockholm in recent years, but it’s been a trickle rather than a torrent.
Last year, Carolyn Bertozzi, who won the chemistry prize, was the only female winner of a science prize.
There were no female science recipients in 2021 or in 2019, when the Nobel committee asked nominators to consider diversity in gender, geography and field.
Astrophysicist Andrea Ghez shared the physics prize in 2020, the same year as Doudna and Charpentier’s chemistry win.
5 women who should have won a Nobel Prize Pendlebury said he believes lack of diversity on the Nobel stage is essentially a pipeline problem.
“They’re looking at work typically published 20 or 30 years ago, when the number of women in science at elite levels was not as much as it is today,” he said.
“And so I think as time goes forward, you see more and more women being selected.
” Others point to the issue as more evidence of systemic bias in science, with women already less likely to be given credit or named as lead author on scientific papers.

“There are several women who made Nobel-level contributions to science, contributions for which male colleagues were awarded, but they were not,” said Naomi Oreskes, a Henry Charles Lea Professor of the history of science and an affiliated professor of Earth and planetary sciences at Harvard University.
“These examples prove that even when there were qualified women, they were systematically passed over.
” Rees attributes the diversity problem to a lack of transparency.
The Nobel short list is secret, as are the nominators, and documents revealing the details of the selection process are sealed from public view for 50 years.
Of course, these flaws and gaps only matter because the Nobels are far better known than other science prizes, Rees added.
He prefers so-called challenge prizes, such as the XPrize, which incentivize future efforts to tackle an important problem, rather than rewarding past success.
The Nobel Prize in physiology or medicine will be announced on Monday, followed by the physics prize on Tuesday and the Nobel Prize in chemistry on Wednesday.
The Nobel Prize for literature and the Nobel Peace Prize will be announced on Thursday and Friday, respectively.
